resources.string: If you are in a moving vehicle, stop as quickly and safely as possible and stay in the vehicle. Avoid stopping near or under buildings, trees, overpasses, and utility wires. Proceed cautiously once the earthquake has stopped. Avoid roads, bridges, or ramps that the earthquake may have damaged.

Look around places where you spend time.
 Identify safe places such as under a sturdy piece of furniture or against an interior wall in your home, office or school so that when the shaking starts you drop to the ground, cover your head and neck with your arms, and if a safer place is nearby, crawl to it and hold on.
 Practice how to “Drop, Cover, and Hold On!”
 To react quickly you must practice often. You may only have seconds to protect yourself in an earthquake.
 Before an earthquake occurs, secure items that could fall and cause injuries (e.g., bookshelves, mirrors, light fixtures). Store critical supplies (e.g., water, medication) and documents.
 Plan how you will communicate with family members, including multiple methods by making a family emergency communication plan.
 When choosing your home or business, check if the building is earthquake resistant per local building codes.

Stabilize the object.
 This can be done a number of ways, the most popular being wrapping the area around the wound so the object will not wiggle.
 However there are alternatives to this, and if you cannot find a bandage stabilizing the object with your other hand works as well.
 CLEAN THE WOUND.
 This is a critical step in caring for a wound of this nature, as leaving a potentially foreign object within contact of the bloodstream will often lead to infection.
 Wrap to prevent blood loss and apply pressure AROUND the wound.
 This is where people make the most mistakes since applying pressure directly to the wound may inflict a considerable amount of pain.
 Additionally, DO NOT REMOVE THE OBJECT.
 Removing an impaled object from the wound may inflict even more blood loss and pain due to the nature of the object.
 If you are sure that it is a flat object with no edges for skin to catch on, DO NOT REMOVE IT,
 this is because no matter how “sure” you think you are about an object it is always a better idea to let medical professionals take care of the wound.
 Monitor yourself for symptoms of shock, these may include vomiting nausea or clammy and cold skin.

Immobilize the head or neck or back, depending on the area of injury
 Protect the neck or spine from twisting or moving. A good solution for this is to use a round object under the head or neck.
 For the next 24 hours, monitor the injury. Ensure that the victim is alert by waking them every two hours, should they fall asleep.
 DO NOT CONSUME ANY FORM OF SEDATIVE OR ALCOHOL!
 This is an important part of caring for a head or neck injury. Due to the possibility of brain trauma, it is unwise to fall asleep without ensuring someone will check you frequently for consciousness
 If you are bleeding from the scalp, control bleeding by applying pressure to the edges of the wound. If this cannot control bleeding, apply direct pressure with caution.
 DO NOT WASH THE WOUND UNLESS INSTRUCTED TO BY MEDICAL PROFESSIONAL

Stop any bleeding, then determine what kind of splint is needed, if medical help is not nearby.
 Soft splints are for breaks that are some degree of mobile, it will not hurt as much to wear, however the limb will be able to move more than a rigid splint; possibly producing pain.
 A good way to make a soft splint is by taking a soft object (possibly a pillow) and using it for cushioning around a standard anatomical splint.
 Rigid splints are good for breaks that cannot afford to be moved much. They will be slightly more painful to wear than a soft splint, however they will reduce movement and ensure the bone will not undergo any pain
 Should medical care not be within reach, continue to check on the wound's healing periodically and maintain focus.
